The AI SDK is to provides a framework and execution environment for simplifying the deployment, execution, monitoring, and troubleshooting of third-party Machine Learning Model AI Applications.
AI SDK is provides a framework and execution environment for simplifying the deployment, execution, monitoring, and troubleshooting of third party Machine Learning Model AI Applications.

header: AI SDK for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps)

header: Technology and Tools for AI SDK

content.text: AI SDK is based on following opensource frameworks:
content.header: Technology and Tools for AI SDK
Technology and Tools for AI SDK

content.text: Blue Planet has extended and integrated above open source frameworks to provide complete solution for MLOps.
content.header: Technology and Tools for AI SDK
Technology and Tools for AI SDK

content.text: Kedro is an open-source Python framework used to author Machine Learning Pipelines. (Commonly used by AI and ML practitioners to create reproducible, maintainable, and modular data science or machine learning code)
The main goal is to address shortcomings caused by using glued code from Jupyter notebooks in production code. Kedro can be the framework for ML projects.
Kedro is not an orchestration engine by itself. However, it supports the execution of nodes and pipelines on orchestration engines like Airlfow, Argo, Kubeflow, AWS Sagemaker, and more.
AI Apps in AI SDK are represented as Kedro pipelines which are shown or visualized in the dashboard called Kedro dashboard.
Airflow is an open-source framework that supports management, scheduling, and execution of data pipelines (presented as Airflow DAGs).

AI SDK has a package API that integrates with Airflow engine for managing Create, Read, Update and Delete (CRUD) operations of Blue Planet AI Applications are represented as Kedro pIpelines that runs as Airflow DAGs.
An open source platform to manage the ML model’s lifecycle, including experimentation, reproducibility, deployment, and a central model registry. MLflow majorly offers following features:
Minio is a simple storage service (S3) object store that stores model artifacts such as models and code.
Redis is an open source (BSD-licensed) in-memory data structure store used as a database, cache, and message broker.
Blue Planet uses Redis internally to store the status and internal state of various operations.
AI Apps Manager lists all the deployed AI applications along with Resource Monitoring.
To open the AI Apps Manager:
You can perform the following operations in AI Apps Manager:
The following image depicts the activities user can perform on AI Apps Manager page.
Use the Add App option to upload, add or create standard Blueplanet AI Apps.
For example, to add a new AI app navigate to AI Apps Manager, click plus icon:
A Wheel (.whl) file is the standard installer package to add or update an AI App.
The following details provide the descriptions of each option:
The following list is used to name the package uniquely:
For more information about the .WHL file structure, see,
AI App Project Template and Structure
If the installation is successful, you will see the uploaded app in AI Apps Manager.
Edit App option to edit or update any AI Apps which you have uploaded using Add App operation.
To edit an AI App, click the Edit icon, as shown in the following image:
You cannot edit, download, or delete Blue Planet proprietary AI Apps.
You can download only apps that you’ve added. You can’t download Blue Planet AI apps.
You can uninstall only apps that you’ve added. Before you can delete an app, you must download the app, which acts as a backup.
Before running an app, you must define a configuration for it.
Run configuration is divided in two sections
Use Advanced configurations as changing them have significant impact on the app’s execution. For this reason, some advanced configurations are read-only.
Advanced configurations should be done only by an administrator who understands how the configuration will affect the app.
You can schedule when an app runs. The following restrictions apply to app schedules:
Blueplanet Apps have a default recommended schedule interval. You can see it by clicking the Help icon when you configure a run schedule. The following image show an example of a default schedule:
This option allows user to stop an AI App completely.
When a schedule type AI App is stopped while it is in RUNNING state, then:
You can open an AI app pipeline in the following modes:
When you are in edit mode, you can edit parameters for task nodes directly from the dashboard.
This mode allows users to edit parameters for the Task nodes from dashboard itself.
The following image shows view mode.

content.text: The base AI SDK license, BPUAA_AI_SDK is associated with the AI SDK. You must have a base AI SDK license to add or upload AP apps.
In addition, all Blue Planet proprietary AI Apps have their own dedicated licenses to use Blue Planet provided AI Apps.
The following list shows Blue Planet apps and their licenses.:
AI SDK has the following default roles that are used for Role Based Access Control (RBAC) to control role-based access for AI Apps operations:
A user with the AI SDK Admin role, can perform the following operations:
AI SDK read only role, can perform the following operations:
If you get an error message that says you don’t have permissions to perform an action, it’s likely because your role doesn’t allow it. If this happens, contact your administrator.

AI App Project Template and Structure
AI Apps in AI SDK are developed and deployed as Kedro projects.
The following is an example of a directory structure in a Kedro project:

Kedro project is organized into directories and files, that have a specific purpose, from configuration to data processing, testing, and documentation. This structure promotes modularity, reusability, and maintainability in your projects.
The core components of a Kedro project include:

To package a Kedro project, the kedro package command is used. This command packages the Kedro project into a distributable wheel (.whl) file, which you can distribute or deploy to other environments. Below are the steps to package a Kedro project:

The kedro package command creates a .whl file in the dist directory of the project’s root directory. The name of the .whl file is based on the project name and version defined in the pyproject.toml file.
After you run the kedro package, the generated WHL file might have the following structure:

The Kedro framework provides various dataset types to facilitate reading and writing data in different formats and storage systems.
These datasets are defined in YAML format. Below are the YAML format of all the common plugins (dataset inputs and outputs) that are supported in this release and their respective input schemas:
If you require specific types of datasets (plugins) then it can be provided as a Blue Planet professional service, you cannot add a dataset of your own type.
This allows you to read and write data using Apache Spark.

tkedro.extras.datasets.spark.spark_dataset.SparkDataSet: schema:  filepath:    schema:      type: "string"      title: "File Path"      description: "Path on file or S3"  file_format:    schema:      type: "string"      title: "File Format"      description: "Format of the file"  load_args:    schema:      type: "object"      title: "Load Arguments"      description: "Key value pairs to provide to underlying PySpark jdbc function"  save_args:    schema:      type: "object"      title: "Save Arguments"      description: "Key value pairs to provide to underlying PySpark jdbc function"
This allows you to read and write data to relational databases using Apache Spark.

kedro.extras.datasets.spark.spark_jdbc_dataset.SparkJDBCDataSet: schema:  table:    schema:      type: "string"      title: "Table"      description: "Table to read and write data to"  load_args:    schema:      type: "object"      title: "Load Arguments"      description: "Key value pairs to provide to underlying PySpark jdbc function"  save_args:    schema:      type: "object"      title: "Save Arguments"      description: "Key value pairs to provide to underlying PySpark jdbc function"

eth10g.df_risk: type: spark.SparkJDBCDataSet table: "mytable" url: "jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/mydb" credentials: my_db_credentials load_args:  properties:    driver: org.postgresql.Driver save_args:  mode: append  properties:    driver: org.postgresql.Driver
This allows you to read and write text data either from or to local or s3path.
This allows you to loads/ or saves data from or to a Parquet file using an underlying filesystem (example: local, S3, GCS).
processed_pm_list:  type: pandas.ParquetDataSet  credentials: minio_credentials  filepath: s3://mybucket/run_data/bpa_mnist/data/02_intermediate/processed_pm_list.parquet
Blue Planet provides custom SparkJDBCDataSet which allows you to read data from and write data to relational databases using Apache Spark.

bpa_base.data_types.bpa_spark_jdbc_dataset.BpaSparkJdbcDataset:  schema:    table:      schema:        type: "string"        title: "Table"        description: "Table to read and write data to"    load_args:      schema:        type: "object"        title: "Load Arguments"        description: "Key value pairs to provide to underlying PySpark jdbc function"    save_args:      schema:        type: "object"        title: "Save Arguments"        description: "Key value pairs to provide to underlying PySpark jdbc function"

query_postgres_table_df:  type: bpa_base.data_types.BpaSparkJdbcDataset  format_driver: jdbc  table: 'none'  url: "${postgres_db_url}"  credentials: postgres_db_credentials  load_args:    properties:      auth-type: basic      driver: org.postgresql.Driver      query: >        select count(*) from mytable where type=${params.record_type}    toPandas: ''  save_args:    properties:      driver: org.postgresql.Driver      auth-type: basic

query_clickhouse_table_df:  type: bpa_base.data_types.BpaSparkJdbcDataset  format_driver: jdbc  table: 'none'  url: "${clickhouse.db.url}"  credentials: clickhouse_db_credentials  load_args:    properties:      auth-type: basic      driver: com.clickhouse.jdbc.ClickHouseDriver      query: >        SELECT count(*) from mytable    toPandas: ''  save_args:    properties:      driver: com.clickhouse.jdbc.ClickHouseDriver      auth-type: basic    mode: overwrite

qquery_neo4j_table_df:  type: bpa_base.data_types.bpa_spark_jdbc_dataset.BpaSparkJdbcDataset  format_driver: org.neo4j.spark.DataSource  table: 'none'  url: "${neo4j.db.url}"  credentials: neo4j_credentials  load_args:    properties:      auth-type: basic      query: >        neo4j_query_here  save_args:    properties:      driver: org.neo4j.jdbc.bolt.BoltDriver      auth-type: basic
This allows you to load or save the machine learning models and experiment data using MLflow.

bpa_base.data_types.mlflow_dataset.MLFlowDataSet:  schema:    model_name:      schema:        type: "string"        title: "Model Name"        description: "Name of the model pre-registered in MLflow"    model_version:      schema:        type: "string"        title: "Model Version"        description: "Version of the model pre-registered in MLflow"
This allows you to read and write data to Apache Kafka topics.
schema:        type: "string"        title: "Bootstrap Servers"        description: "Kafka bootstrap servers url"    topic:
description: "Kafka topic to write data stream to"
Creating Deploying Testing Monitoring AI App using AI SDK
This section describes how to create AI App using AI SDK along with deploying and testing.
The following sections describes how to create an AI APP.
The below steps describes how to create kedro application once it is installed.
Preconfigure Kedro Application as per AI SDK Execution Environment.
Based on the AI SDK execution environment the Kedro application must be pre-configured.
The below steps describes how to create kedro application once it is installed.
as it is not required to report telemetry to kedro publicly.
Add dependencies which might use futher
Install the project dependencies using the below command:
and provide the content in the file as mentioned in the below example code.
mlflow_tracking_uri: "${mlflow.url}" # if null, will use mlflow.get_tracking_uri() as a default
credentials: mlflow  # must be a valid key in credentials.yml which refers to a dict of sensitive mlflow environment variables (password, tokens...). See top of the file.
experiment:    name: bpa_l1_l2    restore_if_deleted: True  # if the experiment`name` was previously deleted experiment, should we restore it?
id: null # if `id` is None, a new run will be created    name: null # if `name` runcate None, pipeline name will be used for the run
nested: True  # if `nesruncate d` is False, you won't be able to launch sub-runs inside your nodes

flatten: False  # if True, parameter which are dictionary will be splitted in multiple parameters when logged in mlflow, one for each key.      recursive: True  # Should the dictionary flattening be applied recursively

(i.e for nested dictionaries)? Not use if `flatten_dict_params` is False.      sep: "." # In case of recursive flattening, what separator should be used between the keys? E.g. {hyperaparam1: {p1:1, p2:2}} will be logged as hyperaparam1.p1 and hyperaparam1.p2 in mlflow.

long_params_strategy: truncate # One of ["fail", "tag", "truncate" ] If a parameter is above mlflow limit (currently 250), what should kedro-mlflow do? -> fail, set as a tag instead of a parameter, or truncate it to its 250 first letters?
ui:  port: "5000" # the port to use for the ui. Use mlflow default with 5000.  host: "127.0.0.1"  # the host to use for the ui. Use mlflow efault of "127.0.0.1".

minio_credentials:  key: "${minio.AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID}"  secret: "${minio.AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY}"  client_kwargs:    endpoint_url: "${minio.url}" mlflow:  AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID: "${minio.AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID}"  AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY: "${minio.AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY}"  MINIO_ROOT_USER: "${minio.AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID}"  MINIO_ROOT_PASSWORD: "${minio.AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY}"  MLFLOW_S3_ENDPOINT_URL: "${minio.url}"  MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI: "${mlflow.url}" nhp_db:  url: "${nhp.db.url}"  user: "${nhp.db.user}"  password: "${nhp.db.password}" uaa_db:  url: "${uaa.db.url}"  user: "${uaa.db.user}"  password: "${uaa.db.password}" clickhouse_db:  url: "${clickhouse.db.url}"  user: "${clickhouse.db.user}"  password: "${clickhouse.db.password}"

mlflow:    AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID: "minio"    AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY: "minio123"    MINIO_ROOT_USER: "minio"    MINIO_ROOT_PASSWORD: "minio123"    MLFLOW_S3_ENDPOINT_URL: "http://localhost:9002"    MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI: "http://localhost:5000"  nhp_db:    url: "http://localhost:9000"    user: "user"    password: "pass"  uaa_db:    url: "http://localhost:5435"    user: "airflow"    password: "airflow"  clickhouse_db:    url: "http://localhost:5435"    user: "airflow"    password: "airflow"

header: 5. Modify setup.py so that app can be packaged as per AI SDK deployment env (Consider the project name provided is - kedro-app-demo, please replace with your app name accordingly

content.header: 5. Modify setup.py so that app can be packaged as per AI SDK deployment env (Consider the project name provided is - kedro-app-demo, please replace with your app name accordingly
5. Modify setup.py so that app can be packaged as per AI SDK deployment env (Consider the project name provided is - kedro-app-demo, please replace with your app name accordingly

content.text: from glob import iglob import toml from setuptools import find_packages, setup import os import shutil from distutils.file_util import copy_file entry_point = (    "kedro-app-demo = kedro_app_demo.__main__:main" ) # get the dependencies and installs with open("requirements.txt", encoding="utf-8") as f:    # Make sure we strip all comments and options (e.g "--extra-index-url")    # that arise from a modified pip.conf file that configure global options    # when running kedro build-reqs    requires = []    for line in f:        req = line.split("#", 1)[0].strip()        if req and not req.startswith("--"):            requires.append(req)
content.header: 5. Modify setup.py so that app can be packaged as per AI SDK deployment env (Consider the project name provided is - kedro-app-demo, please replace with your app name accordingly
5. Modify setup.py so that app can be packaged as per AI SDK deployment env (Consider the project name provided is - kedro-app-demo, please replace with your app name accordingly

content.text: def strip_base_path(path):    return '/'.join(path.split('/')[1:]) try:    from distutils.dir_util import copy_tree    copy_tree("../conf", "kedro_app_demo/conf")    copy_file('../pyproject.toml', 'kedro_app_demo/')    copy_tree("../data", "kedro_app_demo/data")    project_toml = toml.load('kedro_app_demo/pyproject.toml')    project_toml["tool"]["kedro"]['source_dir'] = '.'    with open('kedro_app_demo/pyproject.toml', 'w') as f:        new_toml_string = toml.dump(project_toml, f)    setup(        name="kedro_app_demo",        version="0.1",        packages=find_packages(exclude=["tests"]),        entry_points={"console_scripts": [entry_point]},        install_requires=requires,        extras_require={            "docs": [                "docutils<0.18.0",                "sphinx~=3.4.3",                "sphinx_rtd_theme==0.5.1",                "nbsphinx==0.8.1",                "nbstripout~=0.4",                "recommonmark==0.7.1",                "sphinx-autodoc-typehints==1.11.1",                "sphinx_copybutton==0.3.1",                "ipykernel>=5.3, <7.0",            ]        },        include_package_data=True,        package_data={'': list(map(strip_base_path,                                   list(iglob('kedro_app_demo/conf/**/*', recursive=True)) +                                   list(iglob('kedro_app_demo/conf/**/.*', recursive=True)) +                                   list(iglob('kedro_app_demo/data/**/*', recursive=True))                                   )                               ),                      'kedro_app_demo': ['*.toml']},    ) finally:    shutil.rmtree("kedro_app_demo/conf")    shutil.rmtree("kedro_app_demo/data")    os.remove('kedro_app_demo/pyproject.toml')

content.text: Creating a pipeline using Kedro application is collection of nodes that perfroms data processing tasks.

content.text: # Sample data processing (filter inactive customers)  processed_data = customer_data[customer_data["status"] == "active"]  return processed_data

from kedro.pipeline import node, Pipeline  from my_project.pipelines.data_engineering.nodes import process_customer_data  def create_pipeline(**kwargs):    return Pipeline(        [            node(                func=process_customer_data,                inputs="customer_data",                outputs="processed_customer_data",                name="process_customer_data_node",            )        ]    )

from kedro.pipeline import Pipeline  from my_project.pipelines.data_engineering as data_eng  from kedro.pipeline import Pipeline, pipeline  from bpa_base.data_types.bpa_pipeline import BpaPipeline  def register_pipelines() -> Dict[str, Pipeline]:      data_eng_pipeline = data_eng.create_pipeline()      return {          "inference": BpaPipeline(              "data_eng",              "Data Engineering Pipeline",              "More describption",              pipeline([data_eng_pipeline]).nodes          )      }
